turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: ESCORT
turns.text: Anytime.

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: How much farther?

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: Just a little ways.  Up to those trees.

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: Hey, do you mind if I talk a little?  I feel like, I don't know, talking I guess.

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: Funny, I've never been a talker. My wife was always getting on me about that.  'Say what you feel, tell me what's bothering you, you ve got to talk to me.'  I never would though.  Not really.

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: I don't know.  Part of me wanted to but part of me always said, 'What's she going to be able to do?'  I don't know.  Maybe I didn't trust her.

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: I think I've heard of you.

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: It's possible.

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: You're pretty famous aren't you?

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: I hope not.

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: I know this may seem like a strange question, but can I ask you how much the contract was for -- not to insult you or anything, I know you're a professional, but just for me, I was just wondering.

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: It's a common question.

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: Oh yeah?  I guess we still need to see that price tag.  Like art, right?  You hang some painting that looks like baby-puke in your living room only if it costs a bundle.

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: A dime.

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: One hundred thousand?  That's it? Jesus... Is that a lot?

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: Average.

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: Shit... oh well.

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: I have been thinking about this for a long while.  I knew this day was coming.  I knew someday someone would make the call on me. I never thought about anyone that I had whacked.  What do you call it anyway?

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: Taken.

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: 'Taken.'  That's nice.  When I had someone taken I would call our General Contractor, transfer the money and as soon as I hung up the phone I forgot about them.

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: Everyone who plays the game knows the rules.

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: That's exactly what I told myself.

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: Don't know.  That's how it works.

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: That's what our General Contractor told us but how can you trust someone like that?

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: I thought that I would be thinking about Margaret, or work, or that I'd be having these deep, profound and depressing thoughts but I'm not.  I'm trying to think really profound thoughts, but I can't. It seems very funny to me.

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: What are you thinking about?

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: I'm thinking about Moonpies.  Ain't that funny?  I haven't had a Moonpie since I was ten years old. Right now, I'm thinking how much I'd love one.

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: And an R.C.

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: Can I ask you something?

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: Go ahead.

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: What do other guys do?

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: Everyone handles it differently. Some are ready, some are not.

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: Do they get down on their knees, begging and crying?

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: Some.

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: When I thought about this, that was always there, in the back of my head, that image of me on my knees, crying.  It wouldn't go away and it would really upset me. It was something that I could never get away from... but now, I feel it's okay.  I feel good.

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: Can I ask you a question?

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: Anything.

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: Why didn't you fade?

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: You mean quit?

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: I used to think about it.  I had Margaret.  She wanted kids.  I thought about moving somewhere far away like, Europe.  I could see all of that, the first part, the getting away but I couldn't see that next part.  'Then what?' So I'd stop thinking about it and go back to work.  You understand?

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: KETCHAM
turns.text: Look at that.  I haven't watched the sun set in a million years. Do you mind?

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: You wish to close this account today?

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: That's correct.

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: How would you like the funds?

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: American currency.

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: This will take some time.

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: I have all day.

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: Excellent, senor.  If you could follow me?

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: I'm sorry, but I am waiting for an associate.  Can you hold everything for me until he arrives?

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: Of course, senor.

turns.speaker: RATH
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: KATKA
turns.text: That's true Doug, writers are supposed to write.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: And pay for their drinks occasionally.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: What are you having?

turns.speaker: KATKA
turns.text: A coke, if they have it?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Hey Doug, you want a beer?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Cheers Katka!

turns.speaker: KATKA
turns.text: Naz dravi!.....What do you like about this place, these people, Chris?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: I don't know. It's kind of underground. Doug's right, there's too much crap in this town.

turns.speaker: KATKA
turns.text: I used to think he was right about a lot of things but now I don't know. I thought he was going somewhere but now I think I am wasting my time.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: No, you guys are great together. He'll come through, I'm sure.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: So how's your work?

turns.speaker: KATKA
turns.text: It's okay, they're training me on the cash register and after I hope to work on one of the jewellery counters.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Sounds cool.....Do you think he's serious about squatting a place?

turns.speaker: KATKA
turns.text: I don't know, I don't care. I see too much of him and he's changed. He used to be busy at the magazine. But now he's been doing nothing for months, like he doesn't care about anything, including me.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Well, he sure seems fired up all of a sudden.

turns.speaker: KATKA
turns.text: It won't last, believe me. And you, when will you go back to the States?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: I don't know, maybe I'll enrol for postgrad' studies next Autumn.

turns.speaker: KATKA
turns.text: Your a good guy Chris you deserve a nice girl.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Like you?

turns.speaker: KATKA
turns.text: No, better than me. You know, I have many friends, you should meet more of them.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: He_s the closest we've got to an intellectual.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: What's that? A Democrat with an attitude!

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Fresh from the shrink I'd say!

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Yeah, group bloody therapy time.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: What is it with that Josh guy? Who does he think he is shoving that Reflections rag down our throats?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Son of the American ambassador and a banker - good enough?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Wanker more like, what does he know about writing.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: How to make a buck!

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Yeah right!....I don't know, something isn't right with this place, it's all too sterile and staged. Do you ever wonder why there's no Czechs here?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Because it's in English?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Yeah, but it's not just that. To the Czech mind, any movement, whether political or literary should be underground. If it isn't, then it's not radical and not worthy of a look-in.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: But we are underground?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: No you don't get it. Every cabby in town knows this joint. So where's the mystery, the danger?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Inspirations a fickle thing, you don't realise you had it till it's gone.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: And not even then sometimes.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: You guys having a go a me or what?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: We're only joking.....It is your round though!

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Well, this place is too expensive so you've had it.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Sorry Katka, but I'm with Doug on this.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: You're outnumbered Kat two to one, got to go with the majority, that's democracy.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: What about that squat bar you showed me, is that open on a Sunday?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Yeah, let's check out the low-life.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Anything in it?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: No, just crap. I want some picture frames.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Never heard of K-MART?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: I don't have the money for those Bourgeois traps. Hell, I'm making what a Czech earns.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Yeah and they manage to go to bourgeois joints!

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: It all comes down to ideology and they've lost theirs. If I'd been here ten years ago, maybe they wouldn't be in the mess they are today.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: What's that? Free!

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Just because they've got a choice of four McDonalds, doesn't mean they can afford a cheeseburger.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Give'em a break Doug, all it takes is a little work.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Who's your friend?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: That's Lubosh, the greatest fiddle player in Prague. You must have seen him playing with Johnny on the bridge. ......Come on, let's grab a table.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Hmm..Smells good. Cheers!

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: What did the beer cost?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Fifteen crowns.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: This place is getting expensive too, used to be twelve.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Still, fifty cents ain't bad.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Oh yeah, what's that?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: An alternative literary venue!

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: I ain't sure poetry will go down too well here.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: No, it's the whole idea behind it. How did they get this place?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Squatted it.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Right and not just the bar, Lubosh and his mates took the whole freakin' building.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: So? DOUG Well, there's tons of empty buildings - why don't we get one?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: What we need is a space for real performance art. A cultural exchange for radical expressionism.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: You've got to stop using that word "we" it's getting kind of scary. Right Katka?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: He's not drunk, he's crazy.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Maybe, but someone's got to make a stand.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Like Custer huh?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: These guys think the West is just MTV and Hollywood movies. We've got to show them there's more to it.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Good news comrades, it's better than we'd hoped. Lubosh filled me in on the legal side of squatting here and it's a piece of cake.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Care to elaborate?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Well, providing we're treated like Czechs and we squat something that's not privately owned, we should be in the clear; at least DOUG  until they get an eviction order and bring in the bailiffs.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Amazing, he didn't even say "if".

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: No "if's" or "but's" it's a cinch. Do you want to know what the icing is?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Okay, we're listening. But I'm with Katka on this one.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Well, it's like I said, there's a ton of empty buildings around here and most of them were apparently given back to the city, so they're not private.... Now, Jahn here is an drama student at the University. He knows of a building that they were going to turn into a puppet theatre - they even began work on it, until they ran out of money.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Puppet theatre, don't you need something a little bigger?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: It's big, right Jahn?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Okay, it's in here somewhere. Let's keep it quiet.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: We could make a run for it?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: You were right Jahn, it's a great space..... Hey, Chris. Do you want to come and look?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: No thanks, I think we ought to get going though.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Chris, what if I were to cut you in as partner in this project - together we could make it swing, all it needs is a good clean out and the power on, then we're in business.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: I don't know man, I'll drink beer and shoot crap with you anytime, but this is different.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Damn right it is, it's a chance to do something meaningful for a change, to leave our mark on this town. Hell, you'll probably be gone in another six months and all you'll have done is taught some kids the lines to a Led Zep' song - c'mon, don't run out on me now!

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Alright I give in. But let's not end up in jail. Okay?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: You got my word on it.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: No, I got nothing till Tuesday.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Great. Let's say nine o'clock here tomorrow. Catch you later partner.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: That stinks!

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Yeah, that could be job number two. I think it's a sewer.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: No, but like my dad said, "There's only so many ways you can wire a plug".

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: He was an electrician?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: No, he was talking about girls, I think.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: That makes you an expert I guess.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Too right....Now the other thing we've got to do is start clearing up the rubble. Can you make a start on that?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: I feel like a mole in this joint, so I guess I might as well come out lookin' like one!

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Don't worry, I'll give you a hand as soon as I can.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Just two things. What do I use to shift the stuff and where in hell am I gonna put it all?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Scout around and see if there's something, check that other corridor. If there's nothing, nip out and buy a broom and shovel.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: And put it on expenses?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Sure....As for the crap, I've got an idea.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Somehow, I'm going to have to band-aid that thing since we can't really replace it and then put a walkway over it.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Well, we might as well start filling it in now. As long as you leave enough room around that end of the pipe - so I can get to it, we're set. Use them wooden boards to stop it all spilling into the space - We'll neaten it up later.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: You sure got a handle on that word "we".

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Not bad hey, I think I'll add Sparkie to my resume.....Good shovel!

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Yeah, you're in luck there's two of them, the other's in there.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Later Mate, right now I've got to do the locks on these doors so we don't have to climb through that bloody window every time.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: I thought that was part of the charm!

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: I'll drill the locks and replace the barrels, that way it won't cost so much.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: A locksmith too? Why d'you ever bother with writing?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: I'm making history Chris, nothings going to stop me. There could be a knighthood for us in this, once President Havel hears.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: I'll settle for a pardon. You gotta drill?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: No.....But I think Honza at the office has. You keep shifting this crap and I'll take care of the locks, shouldn't take long. Take a break for lunch and I'll catch you up later.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: And if the police stop by - what do I tell them?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Tell them we're working for the University.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Thought of everything haven't you.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Yep, except a name for this place.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: You're nuts man, Katka's right!

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Wow!....What have you been doing, rolling around in it?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: No, just making my contribution to cultural enlightenment, that's all.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Well, don't get carried away.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: I'll try not to, I'll leave that to you. Anyway, there's still plenty more of it.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Good, I love swinging a shovel.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: No, why?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: 'cause you stink of booze.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Yeah, that was Honza's idea, I had to buy him a few beers in return for the gear.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Tough break.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: I'm an idiot?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Nope, not even close. I've thought of a name for this place and you were the inspiration though.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Really, "The Freeman Centre"?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: No....The Asylum!

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Oh yeah, what's my connection to that?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: None, it's mine - you said it earlier, I'm nuts.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: I've been saying that since we met.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Yes, but it suddenly clicked, this is going to be a crazy place and, since the Commies are used to seeking asylum, we can use that in the marketing.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Perfect, but I can't use it right now, I've got to get these locks done; it's a matter of priorities.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Yeah, I'm beginning to see that.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Just save me a little patch and I'll do it later.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: I don't know but that used to be a window and I think that was a door.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Can you do the lock on it?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: No, it's welded up!....Let's take a look from the inside.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: It must be on the other side of this.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: But how did the wall get here?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: I don't know. This wall isn't like the rest though, it's not all that old either.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: I'd love to get in there.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Don't we have enough already?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: It must be fair old size, suppose it's empty?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: And suppose a little old lady lives there?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: No way, it's sealed - if she's in there she's dead.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Sounds like a good reason to leave it alone.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Just think though, it would make a hell of a cafe, that way we keep the auditorium clear.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Well, it's definitely there - We've just got to get to it.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Why, how in the hell are we going to set up a cafe?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: I'll rig up something don't worry - Do you think I could bash through with that little hammer?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: I don't know Doug, we haven't even got the place together and already you want to extend it.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Don't worry if the old lady's there I'll brick it back up.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Look I gotta get going, shouldn't you have met Katka?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Is it gone four-thirty?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Need any disks?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Yeah, I'll take some.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Yeah, her name's Kavlova, why?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: See if she can donate some paintings or something to hang on these walls, give it a bit of atmosphere.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: You'd be better off with tables and chairs.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Moved on to plumbing huh?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: We got a party tomorrow night. Can't have the place smelling like shit.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: I thought you were gonna throw these?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: I had a better idea, we'll burn them. There's a drum across the road; I was just waiting for the workers to go home.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Destroy the evidence huh.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Have you ever stolen anything?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Nope.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Could you handle it if it was in a good cause?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Like helping a sick kid?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: No, for the Asylum.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Close!

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Just aiding and abetting if it makes you feel better.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: What's that, five instead of ten years jail.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: They'll never get us.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Perfect!

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: It looks new, they might miss one or two.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: We're going to need it all.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Jesus Doug, they'll execute us!

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Stealing's stealing, we might as well get what we need. This'll do for the floor and the walkway too.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Let's split.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Not yet, we need a few lengths of scaffold.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Why don't we just take the whole damn building, brick by brick Doug.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Look at it this way, it's their contribution. If we'd explained it to them, they'd probably have given it to us anyway.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: So why didn't we?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: We don't speak Czech!

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Afternoon!

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Am I late?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: No, not if you've got better things to do.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Who put a bee up your butt?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Like a hand?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: When your ready Son!

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Do you think anyone will really come here?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Well, I think I_ve got a handle on the Czech pysche and I reckon this kind of joint will make _em reminisce about the sixties. Plus we should get a few stray expat_s looking for Kafka.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Fancy some lunch after we_re through with this Meccano shit?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Sure, I think it_s your turn to buy too.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: We'd better get some booze in for tonight.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: You should have said it was Bring-A-Bottle.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: No, I figure once they see the place and we get'em a little drunk, they'll all want to help. We should have that floor done in a day or so.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Here, let's both put in two hundred crowns. That should get nine or ten bottles of wine.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: No beer?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Not on the opening night, wouldn't look right.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: You get the wine and I'll go see if I can rustle up some plastic cups.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Why don't we go together?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: No, it could take me hours. You know what it's like trying to find things in this town, not to mention disposable stuff - I wouldn't think they've ever heard of them.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Red or white?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Both, see you later.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: I see, you've got your hands too far up your collective arse to pull it out long enough except to drink my bloody wine.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Forget it Doug, it's no good.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Have you cleared all the rubble up?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: No, not yet.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: You're all bloody useless.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Get me a couple of beers and a salami.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: We could make a start on the floor afterwards.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: No, We aren't going to do it.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Thanks. Come on Chris, give me a hand.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: I can't, I've got to split. I have to take a class at two o'clock.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: My God! What happened?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: I fell in love.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: And a tram hit you?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: No, the boyfriend.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: What happened to Katka?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Didn't I tell you, she dumped me Monday night.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: You Romeo's sure pay a high price sometimes - anyone I know?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Holly!

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Couldn't keep your hands off the hired help, huh?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: It just happened.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: She's as American as apple pie too. Have you figured out exactly what it is you despise about them?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: She's cool.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: A fine specimen for conversion.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: What are you on about?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Well, I take it you're going to drag her down to your minimal existence and adjust her mindset.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Don't tell me you really are in love?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Yeah and I got the bruises to prove it. So what?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Nothing, it's just that's when things usually start to go wrong.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Chris, can you do me a favour?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Take the drill back to Honza at the office, I promised to get it back for the weekend and I don't want to show my face there.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: You might make Henry happy......Sure, I'll do it.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Good, and then type up a notice on your computer for tonight's thing, photocopy it and put it up in all the faculty buildings and a couple of the pubs. It'll start at eight o'clock and the bar will be open from seven. Holly and I'll go and get some beer and wine.  Can you bankroll the bar for tonight?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Shit no, it'll be twice cost.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: You capitalist pig!

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: The performance is free what more do you want....I've set that old phone up as a donation box and I'll get Jahn to write out a sign....Okay, let's get going.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Does Jahn's thing have a name?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Hey Jahn.....You got a name for this thing?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: It's me you want, I'm responsible for all this.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: He's lying! I am.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Chris! Tell me some good news.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Tell me some bad news?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: I don't want to ruin your day.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: That bad?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Your too good for this town, Buddy.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: So I hear.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: I had a visit from the British Embassy. They think I'm a stray soccer hooligan.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: They ain't the only ones.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: I stopped by your office. Henry was steaming, he says he's going to throw you out of the window and that you never worked at the Bugler.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: He got that one right.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Honza says they'll print an open letter to President Havel in next weeks edition even if they have to threaten a walk-out.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: They're good guys..... Have you seen Holly?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: No, but I ran into Jahn, seems him and his friends are in big trouble with the University, they might even be expelled.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Damn!

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Did you see a lawyer and go before a judge?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Yeah. I tell you, they're one big happy family over there.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: I don't know, I'm waiting for the transcript.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: You're kidding.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Well, the trial's in two weeks, but I think they've already sentenced me. They just need to check if Siberia can slot me in.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: WE gotta think of something.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Now you're using that word.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: I could try and get a Western lawyer.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: You know, there is one thing I can't figure out. All along they've been bugging me about those files and when I told them I'd burned all that stuff, they went nuts - they told the Consul guy they were medical records?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Well, it seems they've dropped any charge relating to the files.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Lucky break!

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Maybe, but I've started to wonder what those files were all about. Suppose it was old KGB stuff and had the dirt on big people or maybe the personnel records of the secret police, that might explain all the hassle and the cover-up.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Did you see anything in the files?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: It was all in Czech wasn't it.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: What happened to those disks I gave you, have you still got them?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Yeah, somewhere?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Suppose those contained all the file info too? You could have a third or so of it there.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Do you want me to see what's on them?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: No point, it'll be in Czech and God knows what format. But if I'm right, they could be my ticket out of here.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: And if you're wrong.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Siberia.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: What do you want me to do?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Get me one of the disks. Ask a Czech girl to smuggle it in to me this evening. Put the others in a locker and write the details in a note to Reuters and be ready to send it, if this doesn't work. You'd better keep clear of your apartment too. Do you know someone with a phone?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Yeah, Dave Walters.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Good, what's his number?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: 42 56 76......... Okay, you wait at Dave's for my call tomorrow, if you don't hear from me by three o'clock, send that note and get out of the country fast.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Doug, I can't just leave you!

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: You're in the clear, keep it that way, I'll be okay.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: If I cut a deal, I'm not staying in this country and I want Holly to come with me. So, if she doesn't come here today, you're going to have to get her to me tomorrow; after I call, promise?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Sure....Anything else I can do for you?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: You could give me your baseball, so I can drive this bastard nuts.....He's been playing chequers for eight hours and still hasn't won a game.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: God, I think I need a holiday.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Some deal you did there!

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: I should have read the fine print.  I love you Holly, thanks.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: What about me?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Here!

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Time for lunch I think. I'll get the sandwiches. What would you like Holly?

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: I'm not hungry, really.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Yeah, no problem.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: We ain't going to give it away this time, are we?

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: I can't go with him.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Look, I don't care whether you go with Doug or not, but you_ve got to see him before he leaves.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: You don't understand, I can't!

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Listen, Doug took the rap for us all so grab your coat 'cause you're going.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: I made a deal with Josh.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: It was a condition of getting Doug out.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: In return for Doug's freedom, I was never to see him again, I had to - it was his only chance.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Josh didn't get Doug out of jail, he did a deal in return for some computer disks we'd held onto.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: You mean, Josh's father had nothing to do with it?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: You're sure?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Sure I'm sure!

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Well, he should be on his way back to his apartment by now.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Do you know the way?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Sure, it's on the red metro line you....

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: No, by road?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Yeah, pretty well.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Good we'll take Josh's Jeep, come on!

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Take this exit.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: That one?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Yeah!

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Jesus Holly, we got enough time.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Okay, but I don't want to miss him.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Follow that Budjovice sign.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: It's that one isn't it.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Yeah....Shit, those guys have guns.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: There shooting at something.

turns.speaker: HOLLY
turns.text: Doug?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Turn around quick!

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Good morning.

turns.speaker: DIPLOMAT
turns.text: I'm just here to record some details, standard stuff.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: You mean your NOT going to spring me?

turns.speaker: DIPLOMAT
turns.text: I don't know what it is with you bloody hooligans. Not content with causing trouble back home, YOU idiots have to go off and wreak havoc throughout the whole of Europe. And when finally, the police do catch up with you, you expect us to wave a magic wand and get you out, well not this time, I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: So am I.

turns.speaker: DIPLOMAT
turns.text: Now - Your name is Douglas Greenwell, yes?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DIPLOMAT
turns.text: Date of birth, November the fourth nineteen-sixty-two.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DIPLOMAT
turns.text: Your home address is 18 Thornton Avenue, Coventry.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: That's my mum's.

turns.speaker: DIPLOMAT
turns.text: I see, would you like us to inform her of your situation?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: DIPLOMAT
turns.text: Now, have you been read your rights and are you aware of the charges?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: DIPLOMAT
turns.text: Well, I'll try and get that clarified. As I understand it though, the charges include break and enter, theft, trespass, operating an unlicensed facility, vandalism and destruction of government documents - Whatever possessed you to start destroying people's medical records?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: They didn't look like medical files to me.

turns.speaker: DIPLOMAT
turns.text: Well a plea of ignorance won't go far here. Frankly, I think you deserve everything that's coming.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Regards to Her Majesty.

turns.speaker: DIPLOMAT
turns.text: Before you go, did you get those bruises here?

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Sure, they wanted to know if I ever voted Conservative.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Hey, Lawrence how are you doing mate?

turns.speaker: LAWRENCE
turns.text: Doug, haven't seen you for a while.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: I've been around.

turns.speaker: LAWRENCE
turns.text: Have you met Holly? Josh's friend.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: No! Look Lawrence, I've taken over the lease on a theatre downtown and I'm throwing a party tomorrow night to show it off. It's going to be for alternative arts, but I need some help to finish it off, can you put the word out?

turns.speaker: LAWRENCE
turns.text: Sure. Excellent.

turns.speaker: DOUG
turns.text: Here's the details.
